gov.usgs.edge.alarm

Class Schedule

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.usgs.edge.alarm.Schedule

  • public class Schedule
extends java.lang.Object
    Schedule.java If the name of the class does not match the name of the field in the class you may need to modify the rs.getSTring in the constructor. This Schedule templace for creating a MySQL database object. It is not really needed by the SchedulePanel which uses the DBObject system for changing a record in the database file. However, you have to have this shell to create objects containing a MySQL record for passing around and manipulating. There are two constructors normally given:
    1) passed a result set positioned to the MySQL record to decode
    2) Passed all of the data arguments needed to build the same set of data.
    The Schedule should be replaced with capitalized version (class name) for the file. schedule should be replaced with the lower case version (for variables). Both the constructors use the "makeSchedule(list of data args) to set the local variables to the value. The result set just uses the rs.get???("fieldname") to get the data from the database where the other passes the arguments from the caller.
    Notes on Enums :
    * data class should have code like :
    import java.util.ArrayList; /// Import for Enum manipulation
    .
    static ArrayList fieldEnum; // This list will have Strings corresponding to enum
    .
    .
    // To convert an enum we need to create the fieldEnum ArrayList. Do only once(static)
    if(fieldEnum == null) fieldEnum = FUtil.getEnum(UC.getConnection(),"table","fieldName");

    // Get the int corresponding to an Enum String for storage in the data base and
    // the index into the JComboBox representing this Enum
    localVariable = FUtil.enumStringToInt(fieldEnum, enumString);
    Created on July 8, 2002, 1:23 PM

      • Schedule

        public Schedule(int inID,
        java.lang.String sched,
        int alias,
        int online,
        int other,
        int jul,
        java.lang.String why,
        int dow,
        java.sql.Timestamp start,
        java.sql.Timestamp end)
        create a row record from individual variables
        Parameters:
        inID - The ID in the database, normally zero for this type of constructin
        sched - The key value for the database (same a name of database table)
        alias - The aliasID being scheduled (line SEISMIC DUTY)
        online - The targetID of the entity for IN HOURS scheduling
        other - The target ID of the entity for OUT OF HOURS scheduling
        jul - The julian date this schedule applies, zero of if this is a day of week schedule
        why - If julian is non zero, a short text explaining the julian override (Christmas, etc).
        dow - The day of week mask that this schedule applies on (sunday=1, mon=2, tues=4, etc.)
        start - The start time of IN HOURS (date portion ignored)
        end - The end time of IN HOURS (date portion ignored)

      • checkSchedule

        public static int checkSchedule(int targetID,
                java.sql.Connection C)
        this method checks a target ID in the schedule and returns the possibly modified target based on the schedule
        Parameters:
        targetID - The input target ID to check in the schedule (normally a alias like SEISMIC DUTY). Algorithm if a julian day is set for this day and target, use it as the schedule if no julian day is set, use the days-of-the-week and target ID to find an applicable schedule if neither is found, return input ID. The return is further affected by the hours in the schedule allowing an "in hours" and "out of hours" ID to be selected.
        C - A connection to the database to use
        Returns:
        The targetid of the target or alias scheduled or if no schedule applies the input target ID
